div.l: Fer in þe north I can not tellen where
This Aleyn maketh redy al his gere
And on an hors þe sak he caste anoon
Forth goth Aleyn þe Clerk. and also Iohn
With good swerd and with bokeler by his side
Iohn knewe the weye hym neded no gide
And atte melle þe sak a doıı̄un he layth
Aleyn spak first al heyle Symond in fayth
How fares þi fayre doughter and þi wyf
Aleyn welcome qduod Symkyn be my lyf
And Iohn also how now what do ȝe here
By god qduod Iohn · Symond nede has na pere
Hym bihoues to s̉erue hym self þᵗat has na swayn
Or ellis he is a fool as clerkes sayn̄
Oure Maunciple I hope he wol be ded
Swa werkes hym ay þe wanges in his heed
And þerfore is I come and eek Alayn
To grynde oure corn · and carye it ham agayn̄
I pray ȝow spedes vs hethen þat ȝe may
It shal be done qduod Symkyn by my fay
What wol ȝe done while it is in hande
By god right by þe hoper wol I stande
Quod Iohn and se how gates þe corn gas inne
Ȝit saugh I neủere by my fader kynne
How þat þe hoper wagges til and fra
Aleyn answerde Iohn wil ȝe swa
Than wil I be bynethe by my croıı̄un
And se how gates þe mele falles doıı̄un
In til þe trough / þat sal be my disport
Quod Iohn in faith I is of ȝoure sort
I is as ille a meller as ar ȝe
This meller smyled of her nycete
And thoughte al þis nys done but for a wyle
They wene þᵗat no man may hem begyle
But by my thrift ȝit shall I blere her eye
For al þe sleighte in her philosophie
The more queynte þᵗat þise clerkes make
The more wil I stele whan I take
In stede of floure ȝit wol I ȝeue hem bren
